content:
Hello all,

I'm taking a course on compilers for school and the final project is supposed to be a working compiler. While they recommend people write it for COOL, they accept a compiler for any language in any language. I was wondering if I could pick Rust as my source language and write a very basic compiler for it, would that be feasible for me to write by myself?

If not, I would probably write a compiler IN rust instead. I just wanted some thoughts/tips/advice from the veteran coders on here :)

Cheers!
hmm it depends what you mean by very basic - even if you don't handle macros at all you'll still have to implement type inference and traits
it's certainly possible because mrustc is written by one person, but it's a big project
I not certain asking for help here with a specific school project is a good idea, do you have TAs?

not really. it's a self paced course. I just have online resources and the dragon book. There's no strict timeline. I have the rest of the year to work on it.

By basic, I mean perhaps I could just get the front end working by end of the year it would be acceptable.
that sounds very relaxed, anyways I would recommend sourcing information for doing homework within your academic environment
A subset of Rust shouldn't be too difficult to implement. E.g. no type inference, no generics, no traits, etc. You can build it up slowly one feature at a time.
Just don't expect to be able to compile core or std.
honestly compiling those two crates is probably the hardest thing you can do because they're so tied to the implementation
lots of lang items and cfg(bootstrap)

ya that was the plan. basically go through concepts in the dragon book and apply them for rust. building it up slowly.

I hope eventually I understand the inner workings enough to actually contribute on here. Will be a while but got to start somewhere.

Thanks a lot for your time folks!
btw you don't have to write your own compiler to contribute to rustc :smile:
Hmm, I just assumed one should know how a compiler works before contributing to a compiler! :D How do you mean? :)
you can just jump in :) there are a bunch of issues tagged as E-mentor you could look at
And "rustc" is bigger than the compiler core itself.
oh sweet! I will take a look for sure! Thanks!
There's lots of nearby parts.
I would have chosen my research project based on Rust looking back now
just go back to school and do it :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
eeeh
maybe
or just do a project, then go back to school eventually to get a credential when you feel like it.
what would my thesis be though? something about AI in the compiler maybe, AI guided optimizing compiler.. or should it be "" compiler optimizer
these are the important questions :laughing:
flip a coin. always the best way of making big life decisions :P :D
the AI is partly just to ensure it gets funded
If you want extra funding, throw a blockchain in as well.
you must mean: AI-assembled Rust compiler block-quantums
I've been working on it for months in secret
I have implemented a compiler for a Rust inspired language during a similar course a few years ago.

I took it as a good opportunity to experiment with various ideas i had for Rust frontend at the time. Definitely doable, but depending on what your goal is, doing something other than rust-like can be a better choice.
mostly to learn and understand the compiler design and implementation

e.g. Rust-like frontend can be quite difficult to implement â€“ resolving names can be a slight challenge, for instance. If you're looking to learn more about the backend, codegen and similar, a similicity-focused frontend can still be a good groundwork for experiments in that area.
not sure what a "similicity-focused frontend" is to be honest. but basically you're saying I could get to the backend sooner with a different (simpler) language than rust. right?

Basically. Pascal comes to mind as something that would result in a fairly simple frontend if you want one such. Or you could define the language as you implement the frontend in the first place, stopping at whatever level of complexity you feel is appropriate for a course project.
ya, the course recommends we use "COOL"
it's funny, when they asked us to write a "cool" program. I just wrote a C program that printed "I'm a cool program". that got me some weird looks from the prof. :D
(Though I don't particularly recommend the latter approach, its a very hacky way to approach the problem and requires some foresight to not accidentally design yourself into a pit)

ya I want to spend as much time is needed to get something to work. even if it's not for this course. I could spend time on it and make sure it compiles. since time wasn't an issue I wanted to pick something a bit more complex than COOL or pascal. I thought of Rust since internet is littered with C compilers :D
and dialects of Scheme
Yeah, doing a lisp is nice because you don't have to mess as much with the parsing side.
Alright, I'll go with something like that then. maybe just make up a simple language at that point :D
maybe call it JJON with all your initials since ya'll helped me out :thumbs_up:
remember you came here to know that
you say that as if I'm leaving ;)
I have some contributing to do out here. hopefully soon. just waiting for weekend to start.
when someone inevitably asks where you got such excellent ideas
I got a list of people for the README xD
